title: A Study of the Tasks and Models in Machine Reading Comprehension

sections.mutual-matching attention:
As the substantial component of the mutual-matching layer, mutual-matching attention is aimed at fusing the contextual embeddings of the question, UQâˆˆâ„dÃ—msubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘„superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘šU_{Q}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}, into those of the context, UCâˆˆâ„dÃ—nsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘›U_{C}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times n}, where dğ‘‘d represents embedding dimensionality, mğ‘šm represents question length, and nğ‘›n represents context length. To this end, the first step is to calculate the similarity between the contextual embedding of each context word, ucisubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘–u_{c_{i}} (i.e. the iğ‘–i-th column of UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C}), and that of each question word, uqjsubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘—u_{q_{j}} (i.e. the jğ‘—j-th column of UQsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘„U_{Q}). A similarity function for this purpose, which was originally proposed in BiDAF [ref]30 and has been adopted in many other MRC models [ref]25  [ref]33   , is as follows: where wssubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ w_{s} is a trainable weight vector, âŠ™direct-product\odot represents element-wise multiplication, and [;][;] represents vector concatenation. Besides, another similarity function, which has also been widely adopted    , is as follows: where ReLUâ€‹()ReLU\mathrm{ReLU}() represents performing rectified linear activation, and Wssubscriptğ‘Šğ‘ W_{s} is a trainable weight matrix. By applying any similarity function described above to every (uci,uqj)subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘—(u_{c_{i}},u_{q_{j}}) pair, a similarity matrix Sâˆˆâ„nÃ—mğ‘†superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘šS\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m} can be obtained, where each element Si,j=sâ€‹(uci,uqj)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘ subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘—S_{i,j}=s(u_{c_{i}},u_{q_{j}}). On this basis, the next step is to calculate the context-attended contextual embedding summaries of the question, U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q}, and the question-attended contextual embedding summaries of the context, U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C}, which can be obtained by applying the following equations separately [ref]30  [ref]33: where Softmaxrâ€‹()subscriptSoftmaxğ‘Ÿ\mathrm{Softmax}_{r}() represents performing softmax normalization along the row dimension, Tilerâ€‹(x,y)subscriptTileğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mathrm{Tile}_{r}(x,y) represents tiling a vector xğ‘¥x for yğ‘¦y times along the row dimension, and Maxrâ€‹()subscriptMaxğ‘Ÿ\mathrm{Max}_{r}() represents taking the maximum element of each row. Besides, U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C} can also be obtained by applying the following equation  [ref]25: where Softmaxcâ€‹()subscriptSoftmaxğ‘\mathrm{Softmax}_{c}() represents performing softmax normalization along the column dimension. With U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q} and U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C} obtained as described above, the final step is to fuse them with UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C}, which can be achieved by concatenating the matrices UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C}, U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q}, UCâŠ™U~Qdirect-productsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶subscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„U_{C}\odot\tilde{U}_{Q}, and U~CâŠ™U~Qdirect-productsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶subscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{C}\odot\tilde{U}_{Q} together along the column dimension [ref]30 [ref]25 [ref]33. Alternatively, the matrix concatenation can also be performed over UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C}, U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q}, and U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C} , or simply over UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C} and U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q} when U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C} is not available . 
What is described above is just a general mutual-matching attention mechanism, which is more or less different from those for practical MRC models. For example, SLQA+  applies the following equation to obtain U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C}: and also fuses U~Csubscript~ğ‘ˆğ¶\tilde{U}_{C} with UQsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘„U_{Q} as well as U~Qsubscript~ğ‘ˆğ‘„\tilde{U}_{Q} with UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C} by applying a gated fusion method. Besides, Match-LSTM  uses an attention-wrapped RNN to process UCsubscriptğ‘ˆğ¶U_{C} based on UQsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘„U_{Q}. Specifically, given the input ucisubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘–u_{c_{i}} and the hidden state hiâˆ’1subscriptâ„ğ‘–1h_{i-1} at each time step, it first calculates zisubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–z_{i}, an attended summary of UQsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘„U_{Q}, as follows: where wzsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘§w_{z} is a trainable weight vector, Tanhâ€‹()Tanh\mathrm{Tanh}() represents performing hyperbolic tangent activation, and WQsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘„W_{Q}, WCsubscriptğ‘Šğ¶W_{C}, and WHsubscriptğ‘Šğ»W_{H} are trainable weight matrices. Then it updates the hidden state with both ucisubscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ğ‘–u_{c_{i}} and zisubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–z_{i} as follows: Based on Match-LSTM, R-NET  modifies the attention-wrapped RNN by adding a gate to the update of the hidden state as follows: where Sigmoidâ€‹()Sigmoid\mathrm{Sigmoid}() represents performing sigmoid activation, and WGsubscriptğ‘ŠğºW_{G} is a trainable weight matrix. As a result, the update of the hidden state is somewhat affected by the relevance of the current context to the question.
